342. This [cooking] can be done in a simple, healthful, and easy manner, without the use of lard, butter, or flesh meats. . . . Skill must be united with simplicity. To do this, women must read, and then patiently reduce what they have read to practise. Many are suffering because they will not take the 
                                                                           78
trouble to do this. . . . It is a religious duty for those who cook to learn how to prepare healthful food in different ways, so that it may be eaten with enjoyment. . . . What branch of the education of a young lady can be so important as this?--T., V. I, pp. 681, 682.
